atk-s0502a3:94_6: After setting it aside, the corpse bathed and bathed in warm water. When the sun was finished, they put down.
atk-s0502a3:94_7: And the ladies of the hook, pulled back, and placed it in water.
atk-s0502a3:94_8: When the last piece was cried, they also cut it out.
atk-s0502a3:94_9: He wears a robe, dressed in ocher robes, and made a bed with one foot.
atk-s0502a3:98_0: Whenever this body is full of earth, they’ll lie down on the ground, with the bed in the air, above the ground.
atk-s0502a3:98_1: They’ve cut the part of the attraction, the repulsion, and knowledge of the consciousness.
atk-s0502a3:98_3: tossed aside like a useless log.
atk-s0502a3:98_4: Dabba, the Mallian swept away by the wilderness, wobbled and fell off. He cuts it down right there, box, closely with sugar, and thimble. And the rest is thirteened, borough, and thirteen it on the rot, thinking,
atk-s0502a3:98_5: A Dabba who comes from the Mallian and who came out to stay in the public meeting hall, cuts her the rank, and only his own enjoyment, thinking that it is only for myself.
atk-s0502a3:98_6: But they can tickle up on the feet and the beds or benches, or the winds.
atk-s0502a3:98_7: But in this life-form, it’s tormented by one-and-a-half months of fortnights, crooked, leaning on the ground, and this body is enough for the whole world—this is called “osmon”.
atk-s0502a3:99_0: He lived for two hundred years, many thousands, and many hundreds of thousands of years. They have stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld.
atk-s0502a3:99_2: The teacher took possession of his reconciles, and made a choposewood.
atk-s0502a3:99_3: The monks asked them about the Teacher,
atk-s0502a3:99_6: ‘But what kind of mendicant must have been performed such a state of perfection? What can a mendicant once-returner? What’s the banyan tree for attaining perfection?’
atk-s0502a3:99_7: ‘This is why I have done all my deeds.’
